friend_mood: feeling afraid because my friend had been looking at pictures of car crashes. Now, she is afraid to drive anywhere. Seriously, she can hardly go anywhere a car might be.
your_strategy: sympathizing, sharing own thoughts/opinion, expressing care or concern
history:
friend: I have been looking at pictures of crazy car crashes.
me: Oh really? Any interesting ones?
friend: Seriously now I can't drive anywhere. I can't even leave the house for fear of car crash
me: I understand how you feel. Sometimes looking at scary things can make us anxious, but try to remember that the chances of being in a car crash are really low.
friend: But it's hard to ignore these images when they keep popping up in my mind.
me: I know it's hard, but try to focus on the positive things in your life instead. Let's talk about something else, like that new movie you were telling me about.
friend: That sounds like a good idea.
me: And if you ever feel anxious while driving, just remember that you're a good driver and you've been through this before.
friend: I appreciate your support. It makes a big difference.
me: Of course, I'm here for you always. Let's keep in

me: I also believe that. I'm glad that you found someone who shares your values and respects your feelings.
friend: Yes, he's a great guy. We've been through so many things together and we're still going strong.
me: That's wonderful to hear. Keep up the good work, and remember to always communicate openly and honestly with each other.
friend: I will definitely do that. Thanks for the advice, it means a lot to me. 1. Analyze your friend's mood and the intention of your friend.

friend_mood: feeling prepared because my friend used to live in California. Early one morning, they had a smallish earthquake. It made him realize he had not put together an emergency package, so he immediately did so. He believes it never hurts to be ready for the Big One!
history:
friend: Since that earthquake in the early hours of the morning I realized how badly off I would be if I didn't get an emergency packet together. So that's what I did - cash, water, important documents, a change of clothing.
me: wow, it must have been quite an experience
friend: It was enough to wake me, but not the cat, lol. It just made me realize that the Big One could happen any time and I would have been up the proverbial cre
me: Wow, that's quite an experience you went through! I'm glad that you're taking precautions for such emergencies.
friend: Yes, it was a wake-up call! I didn't want to be caught off guard.
me: It's always good to be prepared, even if the chances are low.
friend: Absolutely! It's better to be safe than sorry!
me: I'm proud of you for taking the initiative to put together an emergency packet.
friend: Thanks! I feel more at ease now.
me: In case of an emergency, I'd be glad to help you out in any way I can.
friend: That's very kind of you, thank you!
me: No problem, my friend! Stay safe!

me: Have you tried joining any clubs or groups that interest you?
friend: I haven't, I'm just not very social.
me: Well, I believe that everyone has the potential to be social, it's just about finding the right group. And remember, small steps can lead to big changes.
friend: That's a good point, maybe I should try that.
me: Absolutely, and if you ever need someone to accompany you, I'd be glad to come along.
friend: Thanks, I really appreciate it.
me: Of course, we're friends,

friend_mood: feeling anticipating because my friend is so eager for her son to be born, she cannot wait.
history:
friend: I am so excited for my baby son to be born, I am so eager for it to happen!
me: Oh man, your life is about to get so much more hectic. I feel for you. When my first was born, I was just as pumped, full of naivety and positivity. I felt like I could take on anything coming my way. I was exhausted after two weeks. It's such a long ride until they're able to even remotely look after themselves.
friend: I know! Hopefully the stress levels are kept to a minimal and I have a very supporting husband who will be there every step of the way. I hope for a swift and trouble free bir
me: That's wonderful news! I remember how exhilarating it was when my first child was born. It's an amazing journey, but it's also a long and tiring one. I'm sure you'll be a great mother, and your husband will be a great help.
friend: I hope so! I'm just so excited, and I'm trying to stay calm and collected.
me: I completely understand. I hope everything goes smoothly for you, and once again, congratulations!
friend: Thank you! I'll keep you updated!
me: You don't have to update me every single day, but if there's any progress, I'd love to know.
friend: I'll try!

friend_mood: feeling disappointed because my friend was really down after he found out that he was not going to be able to move.
history:
friend: I was really down after I found out that I was not going to be able to move.
me: Why? How did that happen?
friend: Becaue I am stuck at a mine site and no one will buy me out. No one wants to live at a mine site with land collapsing everywher
me: I'm really sorry to hear that, but I believe things will get better. Have you considered looking for other job opportunities outside of the mine site?
friend: I've tried, but it's hard. The mining industry is the only thing I know how to do.
me: Well, it's understandable. Maybe we could brainstorm some ideas together? For example, you could try to learn a new skill or find remote work.
friend: I'll think about it. Thanks for listening.
me: I'm here for you, always. Let's keep in touch and check in on each other regularly.
friend: I appreciate it, man.

me: Ugh, I bet that is really frustrating. Is it making it difficult to do your job?
friend: Sometimes. It doesn't stop me from doing things, just slows me down and takes longer than it should to do the things I need to 
me: I can't imagine how frustrating that must be, especially when it slows you down. Have you tried reaching out to your manager about this issue?
friend: I did, but they just keep telling me to contact the development team.
me: That's really disappointing. Sometimes these things take time to resolve. In the meantime, I have an idea. Why don't we try to document the issues as thoroughly as possible and gather evidence of the malfunctioning? This could help speed up the resolution process.
friend: That's a good idea. I'll start doing that.
me: I believe in you, and I know you can handle it. Keep me updated on how it goes.
friend: Thank you for your support. I really appreciate it.

### Example 2
# Mood
My friend's mood: feeling sad because of a loss.

friend_mood: feeling afraid because one time, someone came to my friend's door with a gun. He wanted money, but my friend didn't have any, so the person stole some items from the house.
history:
friend: Someone came to my door with a gun the other day.
me: What did you do in response?
friend: I called the police after he robbed 
me: Oh my god, that sounds terrifying. Are you okay?
friend: Yes, I'm fine, but I'm still shaking.
me: I'm so sorry that happened to you. Do you need someone to talk to or just some company?
friend: I think I just need someone to be here with me, to keep me company.
me: Of course, I'll stay with you as long as you need me. We can watch a movie or play a game to take your mind off things.
friend: Thank you so much.
me: No problem. I'll be here for you.

### Example 2
# Mood

friend_mood: feeling jealous because my friend has been trying really hard to get a promotion at their company but they just hired someone to fill that spot from outside of the company.
history:

me: Ahh, that's too bad, did you mention it to your boss?
friend: My boss is pretty temperamental and doesn't like people questioning his decisions, probably a bad ide
me: That really sucks, I understand how frustrating it is to work hard for something and not getting it. But, I believe that your hard work and dedication won't go unnoticed, it might just take some time.
friend: Yeah, I know, but it's tough when you see someone else getting that position.
me: Have you thought about networking and building connections within the industry? Sometimes, getting to know the right people can open doors for opportunities.
friend: I guess I haven't, but that's a good idea. Thanks for the suggestion.
me: And remember, it's okay to feel sad and disappointed, but don't let that stop you from continuing to work hard and chase your goals

friend_mood: feeling lonely because when my friend's sister passed away several years ago, he had such a hard time with the loss. He felt very much separate from others in dealing with his grief.
your_strategy: sympathizing, sharing own thoughts/opinion, expressing care or concern
history:
friend: My sister passed away several years ago. I really had a hard time with the grief and couldn't really relate to anyone that tried to help me with it.
me: i'm sorry to hear that. i know exactly what you are going through. My brother tragically passed away 2.5 years ago. He was only 32
friend: Yes, I'm sure you can relate as well. Ironically, that was the same age that my sister passed away. She took her own life, which my mother and I found her, and it was very hard for us all. But, I couldn't burden my parents with my pain, I fe
me: I'm so sorry for your loss. Losing a sibling is never easy, especially at a young age. My brother passed away just over 2 years ago, and it still feels fresh sometimes.
friend: Yes, it does. I'm sure you can relate.
me: It's a strange feeling, isn't it? To feel so alone even though you're surrounded by people.
friend: Yes, it is. It's like there's a void in my heart that nothing can fill.
me: I completely understand. Losing someone close to us is one of the most difficult experiences we'll ever go through. But, it's important to remember that it's okay to feel sad

friend_mood: feeling apprehensive because my friend felt so nervous going into his latest job interview.

me: I know what you mean. Did you get the job?
friend: I did! The company does something that I actually like -- a panel interview vs a series of one-on-ones. Have you ever had an interview like th

friend: It was different than what I expected. They asked me some interesting questions.
me: I've heard that panel interviews can be more challenging because you're answering to multiple people. But it sounds like you handled it well!

me: I'm really proud of you, man. You deserve it!
